Scenario: Abusive or Threatening Contact by Telephone or Email
Who_Is_At_Risk: Office staff - particularly those handling customer/supplier calls and correspondence
Hazard_Description: A customer, supplier, or other business contact contacts an employee by telephone or email and is verbally abusive, uses threatening language, or engages in persistent harassment or intimidation. Verbal abuse can cause significant psychological harm and is within the HSE definition of work-related violence.
Existing_Controls: Company Violence and Aggression Policy states that verbal abuse of staff will not be tolerated; No formal documented procedure currently exists for staff to follow when dealing with an abusive call
Action_Description: Establish and document a written procedure for handling abusive telephone and email contact. Procedure must state: (1) staff may warn the caller once that their behaviour is unacceptable; (2) if behaviour continues staff may end the call without repercussion from management; (3) staff should report the incident using the company incident log

Scenario: Delivery Drivers - Lone Workers at Customer Premises
Hazard_Description: A driver attending a customer's industrial or commercial site encounters an aggressive or threatening individual. This may be a customer employee, visitor to the customer's premises, or an intruder. Drivers are lone workers with no colleague present to assist or raise the alarm. This is the highest-risk scenario in this assessment due to the combination of lone working and attendance at premises not under the company's control.
Existing_Controls: All deliveries to known and established B2B customers - no deliveries to private residences; No cash changes hands at point of delivery; Drivers carry mobile phones and can contact the office
Action_Description: Establish a formal driver check-in procedure: drivers must contact the office on arrival at and departure from each delivery; office must have a procedure to initiate a welfare check if driver has not made contact within agreed time after expected delivery

Scenario: Lone Working on Company Premises Outside Core Hours
Who_Is_At_Risk: Any employee working alone on company premises outside standard working hours
Hazard_Description: An employee working alone on site (early morning start, late finish, or occasional weekend working) encounters an unauthorised person who has gained access to the premises. The primary risk is from an opportunistic intruder rather than a known individual. The lone worker is more vulnerable due to the absence of colleagues nearby.
Existing_Controls: CCTV installed and operational; Premises are lockable; Staff carry mobile phones
